key_issues: Omission of Negative Impacts: The provided evidence focuses on positive initiatives but omits any mention of the company's massive water footprint or the well-documented controversies regarding its operations depleting local water sources in water-stressed communities.

Lack of Scale and Data: The evidence mentions specific projects but provides no quantitative data on their impact (e.g., liters of water replenished) relative to the company's total water consumption. This makes it impossible to assess if the stewardship efforts are meaningful in scale or merely token gestures.

Potential for 'Greenwashing': The combination of positive, company-promoted stories with skepticism from a credible NGO like Greenpeace is a classic indicator of potential greenwashing, where positive actions are highlighted to distract from a larger, negative operational reality.

supportive_evidence: Multiple web sources confirm that Coca-Cola has publicly set a target to recycle 100% of its packaging (or plastic bottles) by 2030.
key_issues: The evidence confirms this is a corporate *goal* or *target*, not a guaranteed future achievement. The claim's wording implies a certainty that the evidence does not support.
There is a significant omission of context regarding the feasibility of this goal and current progress towards it. The evidence only confirms the existence of the pledge.

The provided NGO evidence is flawed; the Greenpeace quote is incomplete, and other sources attributed to Greenpeace and Amnesty International appear to be generic corporate statements, not independent analysis.

articles.full_text:
Coca-Cola Bottlers Japan's Commitment to ESG

Importance of the FTSE Indices

Creating Shared Value through Sustainability

Coca-Cola Bottlers Japan Holdings Inc., headquartered in Minato, Tokyo and led by President Karin Dragan, has proudly announced its continuation as a constituent of three prominent ESG indices: the FTSE4Good Index Series, FTSE Blossom Japan Index, and the FTSE Blossom Japan Sector Relative Index. These indices, developed by the global index provider FTSE Russell, evaluate companies on their corporate governance, health and safety measures, anti-corruption efforts, and responses to climate change, specifically identifying those that excel in Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) practices.The FTSE indices play a critical role in measuring the performance of companies that meet various ESG standards, making them essential for sustainable investment funds and the evaluation of financial products. By being included in these indices, Coca-Cola Bottlers Japan not only highlights its commitment to sustainability but also reassures investors of its dedication to adhering to best practices in these vital areas.Notably, the FTSE Blossom Japan Index and FTSE Blossom Japan Sector Relative Index are crucial benchmarks for ESG passive investments chosen by the Government Pension Investment Fund (GPIF) of Japan. With this latest selection, Coca-Cola Bottlers Japan has now been recognized across four ESG indices utilized by the GPIF: 1) FTSE Blossom Japan Index 2) FTSE Blossom Japan Sector Relative Index 3) S&P/JPX Carbon Efficient Index and 4) Morningstar Japan Equity Gender Diversity Tilt Index (excluding REITs), as of June 2025.Coca-Cola Bottlers Japan regards the creation of shared value (CSV) through its business as a core aspect of its management philosophy. This approach is central to its sustainability strategy, where the company aims to fulfill its non-financial objectives termed “CSV Goals.” These goals drive numerous initiatives aimed at achieving sustainability, which are actively pursued and executed by the company. Published 06-04-24 Submitted by IBM

Image courtesy of Sustainability Magazine

Originally published by Charlie King on Sustainability Magazine

Sustainability leaders from Coca-Cola HBC, EY and IBM discuss how corporate governance plays into their ESG and wider sustainability strategy

Corporate governance arguably goes under the radar, but senior executives say that should not be the case.

So how is it defined?

Corporate governance is the internal system of practices, controls and procedures a company adopts to govern itself, make effective decisions, comply with the law and meet the needs of external stakeholders.

Jonah Smith, Vice President, Environmental, Social, Governance (ESG) Strategy and Programs at IBM, agrees: “For IBM, corporate governance is about creating innovations, policies and practices that prioritise ESG progress simultaneously with ethics, trust, transparency and – above all – accountability.”

articles.title: Coca - Cola Updates Sustainability Targets With WWF - Stratton Craig...
articles.snippet: Coca - Cola is launching a project that seeks to improve the company´s water efficiency by 25% by 2020, as part of its major sustainability programme.
articles.full_text:
Coca-Cola is launching a project that seeks to improve the company´s water efficiency by 25% by 2020, as part of its major sustainability programme. The brand is also teaming up with the World Wildlife Fund (WWF) in a bid to reduce its environmental footprint, Coca-Cola announced this week.

The updated targets are in addition to Coca-Cola´s existing well-being and community commitments through to 2020. The goals also include sustainable use of energy and packaging, as well as sustainable sourcing of agricultural products used in Coca-Cola´s manufacturing processes. At the same time, Coca-Cola intends to cut carbon dioxide emissions embedded in every single drink by 25% and aims to achieve a 75% recovery rate of bottles and cans in developed markets by 2020.

Muhtar Kent, chairman and chief executive officer of the Coca-Cola Company, commented that the company was firmly committed to addressing environmental challenges and together with its partners will be seeking to manage the world´s natural resources wisely and responsibly.

Carter Roberts, president and chief executive of the WWF, stated that natural resources around the world were under unprecedented pressure as the global population increases. It is the responsibility of businesses to make sure that their own existence is not put at risk by exhaustion of resources. Environmental challenges can be addressed only by working together, he added.

New targets will also be set for Coca-Cola´s almost 300 different bottling partners in 200 countries around the world, the company announced.
